node.text:
.
In our first Thursday episode of We Can Do Hard Things—available right now—we’re discussing how Amanda and I are just Pendulum Parenting: overcorrecting the way our parents parented us. Is the result just messing our kids up in the equal and opposite direction?

We’re also talking about my new experiment of combating my hermit tendency by Saying Yes to anything the universe invites me to. I’m tired already.

Please listen at the link in my bio!

And please make sure that you FOLLOW We Can Do Hard Things wherever you listen to podcasts, so you never miss an episode! 

And please leave a review if you love our podcast. But if you hate it, forget I asked.

We’ve also been working hard to make our show as accessible as possible. Find the episode TRANSCRIPTS at the link in my bio after each show.

Okay, Loves, it’s almost Friday—we’ve got this.
G

node.text:
.
We worry so much about our kids thinking we’re perfect, that everything’s perfect—never letting them see our mistakes and pain, never letting them see us try and fall and get back up again. But maybe we should. Maybe our most pressing duty as parents is not to model how to be perfect but how to be HUMAN: how to be brave and kind and how to carry on and forgive each other, and how to try, try, try again to build our truest, most beautiful life. 

Telling the kids that Craig and I were divorcing was the hardest day of my life. Craig and I talk about that hardest day, the complicated decision to get married in the first place, and how we eventually introduced Abby to the kids, in this episode of We Can Do Hard Things. 
Listen at the link in my bio.

Thanks for listening to the podcast, and thank you for welcoming and loving Craig so beautifully.

node.text:
.
Craig’s on today’s episode of We Can Do Hard Things! Listen at the link in my bio.

Our family moved across the country recently from Florida all the way to California. And in the weeks before our move, people kept asking me, Wait, is Craig coming with you?!?!

This question always jarred me completely. I'd say, of course Craig is coming with us. Craig IS us. We'd just as soon move across the country without Amma as without Craig. Craig is my family. My family just looks different than people told me it should. 

I came across this idea long ago that has stuck with me: The thing that screws us up most is the picture in our head of how things are supposed to be.

Craig is joining us today to discuss how we let go of what family “should be” to embrace the family we have. We are going there. We are talking about it all including: 

1️⃣ Craig’s first two thoughts the moment I sent him “the text.”
2️⃣ How Glennon and Craig told the kids they were divorcing. 
3️⃣ The big mistake Glennon and Craig agree they made in the early days of blending their family.
4️⃣ What Craig says is the most annoying thing about co-parenting with Glennon, and the best thing about co-parenting with Abby.
5️⃣ How Craig really feels about Glennon writing their stories. 

Listen at the link in my bio.

node.text:
.
Since the world tells us in a thousand different ways that our bodies are broken, wrong, out of control, and less-than, it’s important to have someone remind us that it’s our world that’s crazy: We're not crazy, we're goddamn cheetahs. 

That someone for me is usually my sister. Here's Amanda’s gentle reminder from this week’s episode about why BMI is horseshit. 

We can do hard things. Like learn to wage peace with our bodies in a world that insists we be at war with ourselves. Listen at the link in my bio.

node.text:
I read this section of UNTAMED in a steepled, echoing church sanctuary on the first night of the book tour right before our world changed. That night, a thousand people looked on, but I shared it for one person—my wife—who sat in the front pew that night.

In this week’s podcast episode, Abby opens her soul and pain and healing story to us.

No one, but no one, has more God in them than you do—so be brave. No one, but no one, has less God in them than you do—so be kind.

Listen to We Can Do Hard Things at the link in my bio.

node.text:
Y'all we're recording a We Can Do Hard Things podcast episode about sex this week and we want to know what you'd like to hear us address. Questions? Topics? What should we talk about!???
We love you. This is hard for me but we can do hard things. I want this part of our lives to be less taboo and confusing and lonely. 
Kay!!! Go!!!

node.text:
.
Today on the We Can Do Hard Things podcast, we have the most intimate conversation we've ever had. Abby shares about how she learned as a child from her beloved church to hate herself, and how she healed. 

This episode is for anyone who has been through the trauma of being abandoned by, or had to leave, a beloved, foundational community. 

For anyone who has had to choose between who they are and who they love. 

For anyone who is still healing from the internalized self-hate they were fed by people they trusted. 

For anyone who has been told ““I disagree with your lifestyle, but I love you anyway.”

For anyone who doesn’t yet know who their children will become, but is hellbent on protecting whatever they will be. 

For anyone who—notwithstanding all the messages from the world—knows we all deserve to be both held and free; to fully belong exactly as we are.

This episode is for all of us.  Listen at the link in my bio. 

Thank you, Abby, for opening your soul and pain and healing to us. I love you.
G

node.text:
Well, hello, my night owl friends,
Do you happen to be, like my sister Amanda, a “revenge bedtime procrastinator” — exhausted and spent but still spending countless hours scrolling social media while you “should” be sleeping because you're so starved for anything that remotely resembles an exhale and it’s the only damn time you get to yourself and by yourself?

You’re not alone. 

Talking about how we can care for ourselves and our needs in this week’s We Can Do Hard Things podcast — listen at the link in my bio. 

Love,
G

node.text:
.
New We Can Do Hard Things episode!  Listen at the link in my bio. 
 
Today we are talking about SELF CARE.
 
We know in our bones that we must prioritize caring for our selves.  And the 450 Billion dollar self care industry is thrilled to intercede — relentlessly selling us their commodified version.

But what is real, deep, inner self care and how do we begin to actually see ourselves and identify our real needs enough to finally get them met? 
 
Listen at the link in my bio as my sister Amanda and I discuss:
1️⃣ How to create lives that we don’t need to escape from.
2️⃣ Why our resentment toward others is our Secret Self-Care Signal.
3️⃣ Why ditching selflessness is the best way to care for others and the world.
4️⃣ How to stop passing down the brutal legacy of martyrdom to our children and
5️⃣ My life-changing spiritual practice: Habitual Quitting.
 
We Can Do Hard Things. Like know our needs and get them met. 
G

node.text:
.
In this week’s We Can Do Hard Things podcast, Abby and I talk about the hard thing of FIGHTING WELL and how we learned that whenever we entered conflict, we would each suit up with a “bulletproof vest” to try to make ourselves invulnerable.  

My bulletproof vest is anger and rightness – my instinct is to fight like a lawyer hellbent on winning her case, instead of a partner trying to get to resolution.  

Abby’s bulletproof vest is shame and fear of abandonment.

We put on these bulletproof vests so we won’t expose our vulnerability – but wearing them makes it absolutely impossible to even talk about – much less resolve – the original conflict, because now we’re just dealing with, and fighting about, each other’s armor.  

Did you listen to this episode?  Did the bulletproof vest resonate with you?  If so, what’s yours?

We Can Do Hard Things: Like Fight Well with the ones we love. 
Listen at the link in my bio.  
G
@abbywambach

node.text:
.

Abby is back joining us in this week’s episode of We Can Do Hard Things! (Listen at the link in my bio.)

We talk about the five fights we have most often, how our fights usually go – and how we finally started FIGHTING WELL. 
 
In our relationship, Abby used to run from conflict.  I do not, thank you very much. In fact, if I were to ever run anywhere (I will not), it would be TOWARD CONFLICT.  As you can imagine, this took some navigating. 
 
Even though my sister Amanda is usually on Abby’s side, she helped explain the value we pro-conflict folks bring to our relationships.
 
When it comes to conflict in your relationships, are you Team Abby (conflict is destructive), or Team Glennon (conflict is constructive)?

I love you @abbywambach. I want to fight with you forever. 

Listen and follow We Can Do Hard Things at the link in my bio.
G

node.text:
.
In our first Thursday episode of We Can Do Hard Things—available right now—we’re discussing how Amanda and I are just Pendulum Parenting: overcorrecting the way our parents parented us. Is the result just messing our kids up in the equal and opposite direction?

We’re also talking about my new experiment of combating my hermit tendency by Saying Yes to anything the universe invites me to. I’m tired already.

Please listen at the link in my bio!

And please make sure that you FOLLOW We Can Do Hard Things wherever you listen to podcasts, so you never miss an episode! 

And please leave a review if you love our podcast. But if you hate it, forget I asked.

We’ve also been working hard to make our show as accessible as possible. Find the episode TRANSCRIPTS at the link in my bio after each show.

Okay, Loves, it’s almost Friday—we’ve got this.
G

EXCITING ANNOUNCEMENT! 

@AbbyWambach, Amanda, and I are now coming to you with a SECOND weekly podcast episode - starting TOMORROW! 

1️⃣ We missed you -- one episode didn’t seem like enough, and we were hearing from you that you felt quite abandoned for the rest of the week.
2️⃣ The responses and the questions you're sending are amazing--and we haven't been able to get to enough of them with just one weekly show.
3️⃣ IMPORTANT: We've been hearing from many of you that you've been missing episodes, so to be sure that doesn't happen, please "Follow" the We Can Do Hard Things podcast on Apple, Spotify, Google, Audacy, Stitcher, Amazon, Overcast, iHeart, TuneIn, or wherever you listen to podcasts. 

Following the podcast is free, takes five seconds, and is easy to do, you just click on your preferred podcast provider at the link in my bio and hit Follow or the plus sign (+) on Apple. 

(We can do hard things, but doing easy things is sometimes very, very hard, so swipe left for how to Follow!)

See you TOMORROW!
G

node.text:
BUCKLE UP, TODAY WE'RE DISCUSSING THE PARENTING ROLLERCOASTER.

On today's episode of We Can Do Hard Things, Amanda and I are talking about how we can make this beautiful, excruciating ride a little bit easier. We discuss:

1️⃣ The 5 things I wish I’d known during those early days with young kids. 2️⃣ Why it’s important to let our kids see us mess up, cry, and lose it every once in a while. 3️⃣ How to let go of Expectation Parenting and embrace Treasure Hunt Parenting. 4️⃣ On teaching kids the most important lesson: How to disappoint everyone else (including you) before they disappoint themselves. 5️⃣ Why if you’re listening to this podcast concerned about how you’re parenting, things are likely already okay.

Listen at the link in my bio. There’s a link to transcripts there, too. 
G

node.text:
.
We worry so much about our kids thinking we’re perfect, that everything’s perfect—never letting them see our mistakes and pain, never letting them see us try and fall and get back up again. But maybe we should. Maybe our most pressing duty as parents is not to model how to be perfect but how to be HUMAN: how to be brave and kind and how to carry on and forgive each other, and how to try, try, try again to build our truest, most beautiful life. 

Telling the kids that Craig and I were divorcing was the hardest day of my life. Craig and I talk about that hardest day, the complicated decision to get married in the first place, and how we eventually introduced Abby to the kids, in this episode of We Can Do Hard Things. 
Listen at the link in my bio.

Thanks for listening to the podcast, and thank you for welcoming and loving Craig so beautifully.

node.text:
At @together.rising, our hearts break for the more than one thousand First Nations people—most of whom were children—who have been found in unmarked graves at former residential school sites in Canada.
 
From 1883 to as recently as 1996, an estimated 150,000 First Nations children were forcibly separated from their families to attend residential schools primarily run by churches. (New York Times) In what "can best be described as cultural genocide," the goal of these schools was to erase the children’s language, traditions, sacred practices, beliefs, and stories. Every aspect of their native culture was stolen in the state-sanctioned forced assimilation into whiteness.
 
The children were subjected to physical and sexual violence, kept in overcrowded dorms while tuberculosis and the Spanish flu spread rapidly. Hundreds of children died as a result of these gross acts of negligence and abuse, as well as by suicide and by trying to escape. (New York Times)
 
Countless children never returned to their families and loved ones, and were left in unmarked mass graves. The discoveries of these graves are part of the enduring history of anti-First Nations and anti-Indigenous violence over hundreds of years not only in Canada but also in the U.S., whose schools were the model for the Canadian ones.
 
We at Together Rising stand with all who knew and loved these children, all survivors and descendants of survivors. We just invested $250,000 to the Indian Residential School Survivors Society (IRSSS)—a nonprofit founded and led by First Nations elders—that has supported First Nations communities for the last 25 years, including survivors of residential schools and their descendants.
 
After the confirmations of the graves, IRSSS sent elders to the communities to provide in-person cedar brushings, smudges, prayers, and other sacred cultural practices. With our $250,000 investment, the IRSSS team will continue to provide on-the-ground support in culturally responsive and trauma-informed ways that only they can, making space for conversations that only they can have. 

Through Together Rising, all of us are on the ground right now with these families. We belong to each other.

node.text:
.
Craig’s on today’s episode of We Can Do Hard Things! Listen at the link in my bio.

Our family moved across the country recently from Florida all the way to California. And in the weeks before our move, people kept asking me, Wait, is Craig coming with you?!?!

This question always jarred me completely. I'd say, of course Craig is coming with us. Craig IS us. We'd just as soon move across the country without Amma as without Craig. Craig is my family. My family just looks different than people told me it should. 

I came across this idea long ago that has stuck with me: The thing that screws us up most is the picture in our head of how things are supposed to be.

Craig is joining us today to discuss how we let go of what family “should be” to embrace the family we have. We are going there. We are talking about it all including: 

1️⃣ Craig’s first two thoughts the moment I sent him “the text.”
2️⃣ How Glennon and Craig told the kids they were divorcing. 
3️⃣ The big mistake Glennon and Craig agree they made in the early days of blending their family.
4️⃣ What Craig says is the most annoying thing about co-parenting with Glennon, and the best thing about co-parenting with Abby.
5️⃣ How Craig really feels about Glennon writing their stories. 

Listen at the link in my bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glennon Doyle on July 18, 2021. May be a Twitter screenshot of text that says 'Glennon Doyle @GlennonDoyle Motion to cut out the whole: sir and ma'am business. Why are strangers guessing each other's genders? What was once considered polite is impolite in the extreme. Let's do better now that we know better.'.

node.text:
When "manners" and kindness turn out to be two different things: let's choose kindness. 

For your consideration, with love and grace. 

G

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glennon Doyle on July 17, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'WE MUST DO WHAT WE NEED ΤΟ DO. THOSE WHO DISAPPROVE WILL EITHER COME AROUND OR STOP COMING AROUND EITHER WAY, LOVELY. GLENNON DOYLE'.

node.text:
What if they get mad? 
What if they don't understand? What if they leave?

They might. I've certainly lost people. What I've learned is that the people I lose when I refuse to lose myself are the people I was meant to lose. And the people I find are the people I was meant to find. And with them: I can be both held and free. 

I didn't pretend to get them so I don't have to pretend to keep them.

It's hard to refuse to abandon yourself. But it's also hard to abandon yourself. It's all hard. So I guess we just gotta choose our hard. 

Anyway. I just love ya. You're doing great under this RIDICULOUS set of circumstances we call: life. 

XO, 
G

#GetUntamed

node.text:
.
Since the world tells us in a thousand different ways that our bodies are broken, wrong, out of control, and less-than, it’s important to have someone remind us that it’s our world that’s crazy: We're not crazy, we're goddamn cheetahs. 

That someone for me is usually my sister. Here's Amanda’s gentle reminder from this week’s episode about why BMI is horseshit. 

We can do hard things. Like learn to wage peace with our bodies in a world that insists we be at war with ourselves. Listen at the link in my bio.
